facts.text: Messrs. Brijlal Manilal and Company is a bidi factory situated in Sagar.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Brijlal Manilal and Company is a bidi factory situated in Sagar. The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager. The Company manufactures bidis.

facts.text: The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager. The Company manufactures bidis. The process of manufacture, so far as is relevant to the question raised, is carried out in two stages.

facts.text: The Company manufactures bidis.

anchor.surface_text: The Company manufactures bidis. The process of manufacture, so far as is relevant to the question raised, is carried out in two stages. The first stage The management enters into a contract with independent contractors, known as Sattedars, for the supply of bidis locally.

facts.text: The management enters into a contract with independent contractors, known as Sattedars, for the supply of bidis locally.

anchor.surface_text: The first stage The management enters into a contract with independent contractors, known as Sattedars, for the supply of bidis locally. The documents embodying the terms of the contract entered into by the Sattedars were not produced in the case. But the terms of the contract are not in dispute.

facts.text: The documents embodying the terms of the contract entered into by the Sattedars were not produced in the case. But the terms of the contract are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The documents embodying the terms of the contract entered into by the Sattedars were not produced in the case. But the terms of the contract are not in dispute. The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves.

facts.text: The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves.

anchor.surface_text: The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves. Some of the Sattedars maintain a small factory where they get bidis manufactured by engaging coolies. Others give tobacco and bidi leaves to outsiders who prepare bidis in their houses.

facts.text: After bidis are rolled the Sattedars collect the bidis so manufactured and take them to the factory directly or through coolies where they are sorted and checked by the workers in the factory.

anchor.surface_text: After bidis are rolled in the Sattedars collect the bidis so manufactured and take them to the factory directly or through coolies where they are sorted and checked by the workers in, the factory. The selected or approved bidis are separately packed in bundles of 10 and 25 and taken by the Sattedars or the coolies in gauze trays to tandul and left there.

facts.text: The management pays the Sattedars the cost of the manufacture of bidis after deducting therefrom the cost of tobacco supplied to them.

anchor.surface_text: The management pays the Sattedars the cost of the manufacture of bidis after deducting therefrom the cost of tobacco supplied to them. Thereafter the second stage of the process of the manufacture begins in the factory.

facts.text: On December 9, 1952, Sri B. V. Desai, the Inspector of Factories, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, visited the factory at 5-30 p. m.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1952, Sri B. V. Desai, the Inspector of Factories, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, visited the factory at 5-30 p. m. At the time of his inspection he found the following persons in the factory Pirbaksha, son of Amir.

facts.text: Thereafter the Chief Inspector of Factories filed a complaint in the Court of the Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, against the appellants for violation of the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Chief Inspector of Factories filed a complaint in the Court of the Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, against the appellants for violation of the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 of the Act, under the former for failure to maintain the register of adult workers with all the prescribed entries duly filled in and under the latter for allowing the workers to work in the factory without making beforehand the entries of their attendance in the register of adult workers.

facts.text: The Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, held that the appellants contravened the provisions of the aforesaid sections and on that finding convicted them under s. 92 of the Act and directed them to pay a fine of Rs. 50 and Rs. 25 respectively on August 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, held that the appellants contravened the provisions of the aforesaid sections and on that finding convicted them under s. 92 of the Act and directed them to pay a fine of Rs. 50 and Rs. 25 respectively. On appeal the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, confirmed the conviction of the 2nd appellant for contravening the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 but set aside that of the 1st appellant in regard to s. 62 but confirmed the conviction for contravening s. 63 of the Act.

facts.text: On appeal the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, confirmed the conviction of the 2nd appellant for contravening the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 but set aside that of the 1st appellant in regard to s. 62 but confirmed the conviction for contravening s. 63 of the Act on March 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, confirmed the conviction of the 2nd appellant for contravening the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 but set aside that of the 1st appellant in regard to s. 62 but confirmed the conviction for contravening s. 63 of the Act. The Revision Petition filed by the appellants in the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur was dismissed.

facts.text: The Revision Petition filed by the appellants in the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur was dismissed on September 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Revision Petition filed by the appellants in the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur was dismissed. As aforesaid with Special Leave of this Court, this appeal was filed against the Order of the High Court.

facts.text: Admittedly the names of the 9 persons, stated supra, were not entered in the register of adult workers maintained by the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the names of the 9 persons, stated supra, were not entered in the register of adult workers maintained by the factory. Neither any notice of the periods of work allotted to them was displayed in the factory nor any entries made beforehand against their names in the register of adult workers of the factory.

facts.text: Sattedar is only an independent contractor, who undertakes to do a specific job of work, i.e., the supply of bidis, directly or indirectly through his coolies, by manufacturing them either in his own factory or by entrusting the work to third parties, at a price to be paid by the management after delivery and approval.

anchor.surface_text: From the aforesaid description of the dual process of manufacture of bidis it is manifest that a Sattedar is only an independent contractor, who undertakes to do a specific job of work, i. e., the supply of bidis, directly or indirectly through his coolies, by manufacturing them either in his own factory or by entrusting the work to third parties, at a price to be paid by the management after delivery and approval.

facts.text: He Sattedar or his coolies neither work in the appellants factory nor are they subject to the supervision or control of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: He  Sattedar  or his coolies neither work in the appellants factory nor are they subject to the supervision or control of the appellants. The coolies or the third parties, to whom the work of making of bidis is entrusted by the Sattedars, are employed by the Sattedars and are paid by them.

facts.text: The Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors who performed their part of the contract by making bidis and delivering them at the factory.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors who performed their part of the contract by making bidis and delivering them at the factory. If the Sattedars, i. e., three out of the nine persons found at the factory, were not workers within the meaning of the Act,

facts.text: The coolies employed by the Sattedars are not workers within the meaning of the definition in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that coolies employed by the Sattedars are not workers within the meaning of the definition in the Act. The evidence discloses a third category of persons who took some part in the manufacturing process of bidis.

facts.text: This appeal by Special Leave is directed against the Order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-This appeal by Special Leave is directed against the Order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur and raises the question of construction of some of the provisions of the Factories Act  LXIII of 1948   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

issues.text: Whether the nine persons found in the factory (Sattedars and coolies) were workers within the meaning of Section 2(1) of the Factories Act, 1948, such that the appellants contravened Sections 62 and 63?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, therefore, would have certainly contravened the provisions of the Act, if, in fact, the said persons were workers in the factory as defined Under the Act. This takes us to the consideration of the definition of the term worker under the Act.

issues.text: Whether a Sattedar is a person employed, directly or through any agency, within the meaning of the definition of 'worker' under Section 2(1)?

anchor.surface_text: But is a Sattedar a person employed , directly or through agency, within the meaning of the definition employed. The concept of employment involves three ingredients : 1 employer 2 employee and 3 the contract of employment.

issues.text: Whether coolies employed by Sattedars are workers under Section 2(1), as employed directly or through any agency by the factory management?

anchor.surface_text: If the Sattedars, i. e., three out of the nine persons found at the factory, were not workers within the meaning of the Act, can it be said that the other persons, who were coolies employed by the Sattedars to enable them to keep up their contract with the management of the factory, were workers as defined under the Act?

issues.text: What is the proper construction of the definition of 'worker' under Section 2(1) of the Factories Act, 1948, in light of conflicting High Court decisions?

anchor.surface_text: There is a conflict of decisions between the Allahabad and the Nagpur High Courts on the construction of s. 2 (1) of the Act.

issues.answer: Requires employer-employee relationship based on control test; excludes independent contractors and their employees

arguments.claim: A Sattedar is an independent contractor who undertakes to do a specific job of work without submitting to control of the factory, and neither he nor his employees are workers under s.2(1) of the Act, so no duty to comply with ss.62 or 63.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants contends that a Sattedar is an independent contractor, who undertakes to do a specific job of work for other persons without submitting himself to their control, and that he or his employee is not a worker within the definition of s. 2 (1) of the Act and therefore the appellants are not under duty to comply with the conditions of ss. 62 or 63 in respect of them.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sattedars lack employer-employee relationship; no control by factory over manner of work.

arguments.claim: The definition of 'worker' is comprehensive enough to include all persons who work in the factory, whether employed by the factory or not.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the learned Counsel for the State argues that the definition of the word worker is comprehensive enough to take in all persons who work in the factory, whether employed by the factory or not.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he work . There is, therefore, a clear-cut distinction between a companytractor and a workman. The identifying mark of the latter is that he should be

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition requires contract of employment with control; excludes independent contractors.

arguments.claim: Employment involves three ingredients: employer, employee, contract of service where employee serves under control and supervision.

anchor.surface_text: The concept of employment involves three ingredients : 1 employer 2 employee and 3 the contract of employment. The employer is one who employs, i.e., one who engages the services of other persons.

arguments.claim: There is a clear-cut distinction between a contractor and a workman; contractor does specific job without control over details.

anchor.surface_text: A contractor is a person who, in the pursuit of an independent business, undertakes to do specific jobs of work for other persons, without submitting himself to their control in respect to the details of the work . There is, therefore, a clear-cut distinction between a contractor and a workman.

arguments.claim: Test for master-servant relationship is right of control over manner of work, as per Dharangadhara Chemical Works precedent.

anchor.surface_text: The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done. ... The principle which emerges from these authorities is that the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work

arguments.claim: Sattedars are not workers as no control by management over their work; they manufacture bidis independently and deliver.

anchor.surface_text: If the test be applied, it is not possible to hold that Sattedars in the present case, having regard to the nature of the work undertaken by them and the terms whereunder their services were engaged, are workers within the meaning of the definition under the Act.

arguments.claim: Coolies employed by Sattedars are not workers as no privity of contract with management; not employed directly or through agency of management.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the coolies were not employed by the management there was no privity of contract between them and the management. It is not disputed that the coolies were not employed by the Sattedars for or on behalf of the management of the factory.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Chapter VI (ss.51-63) indicates workers are under direct supervision and control of management.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the aforesaid provisions indicates that the workmen in the factory are under the direct supervision and control of the management. The conditions of service are statutorily regulated and the management is to conform to the rules laid down at the risk of being penalised for dereliction of any of the statutory duties.

arguments.claim: Management cannot comply with statutory requirements for independent contractors like Sattedars.

anchor.surface_text: The management obviously cannot fix the working hours, weekly holidays, arrange for night shifts and comply with other statutory requirements, if the persons like the Sattedars, working in their factories and getting their work done by others or through coolies, are workers within the meaning of the Act.

arguments.claim: Nagpur HC in Provincial Government v. Robinson does not decide if contractor's employees are workers, as point not raised.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that if this question was raised and decided in the way we did, the conclusion of the learned Judges would have been different cannot make the said decision an authority on a point not raised or decided upon by the learned Judges.

arguments.claim: Nagpur HC in State v. Jiwabhai wrongly gave wide connotation to 'employed' ignoring contract requirement.

anchor.surface_text: If the learned Judges meant by that observation that if a person is found, engaged in some form of activity in a factory, irrespective of whether there was any contract of employment or not between him and the employer, he is a worker, we should express our respectful dissent from the said observation.

arguments.claim: Allahabad HC in State v. Shri Krishna Prasad accepted correct interpretation that requires employment contract.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in State v. Shri Krishna Prasad need not be considered in detail as the learned Judges therein accepted the same interpretation that we have placed on the provisions of s. 2 (1) of the Act

arguments.claim: Neither Sattedars nor coolies were workers, so no offence under s.92 for non-inclusion in register.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that neither the Sattedars nor the coolies found by the Inspector to be working in the factory were workers, as they were not employed by the factory. As they were not workers, the non-inclusion of their names in the register of adult workers or the absence of any entries in regard to them in the said register would not constitute an offence under s. 92 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving this case we would like to make one observation. Our decision is not intended to lay down a general proposition that under no circumstances a Sattedar can be considered to be a worker within the meaning of its definition in the Act.

precedents.citation: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 1

anchor.surface_text: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 1 in the context of the definition of workman under the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947 made the following observations at page 157

precedents.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd v State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: The essential condition of a person being a workman is employment by the employer with a relationship of master and servant; the test is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done.
precedents.cited_holding: The prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work.

precedents.citation: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Coggins Griffith Liverpool Ltd., and another 1947 1 A. C. 1, 23

anchor.surface_text: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Coggins Griffith Liverpool Ltd., and another 1947 1 A. C. 1, 23 , The proper test is whether or not the hirer had authority to control the manner of execution of the act in question.

precedents.case_name: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v Coggins and Griffith (Liverpool) Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: The proper test for master-servant relationship is whether or not the hirer had authority to control the manner of execution of the act in question.

precedents.citation: Provincial Government, Central Provinces and Berar v.Robinson 1

anchor.surface_text: Provincial Government, Central Provinces and Berar v.Robinson 1 considered the scope of the definition of the word worker in the Factories Act.

precedents.case_name: Provincial Government Central Provinces and Berar v Robinson
precedents.cited_proposition: The definition of worker is wide enough to include persons employed in repairing machinery or putting up new machinery even if not in actual use.

anchor.surface_text: The State v. Jiwabhai 2 gave a wide connotation to the word employed under s. 66 1 b of the Factories Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'employed' connotes not only employed on wages but also being occupied or engaged in some form of activity.

precedents.citation: State v. Shri Krishna Prasad Dar

anchor.surface_text: State v. Shri Krishna Prasad Dar need not be considered in detail as the learned Judges therein accepted the same interpretation that we have placed on the provisions of s. 2 1 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that coolies employed by the Sattedars are not workers within the meaning of the definition in the Act. The evidence discloses a third category of persons who took some part in the manufacturing process of bidis.

edges.explanation: Consecutive holdings where h3's finding that persons were not workers supports h4's conclusion that non-inclusion in register is not an offence under s.92.
Holding h3 directly finds that the Sattedars and coolies were not workers, addressing the issue i1 of whether they were workers under Section 2(1) of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that neither the Sattedars nor the coolies found by the Inspector to be working in the factory were workers, as they were not employed by the factory. As they were not workers, the non-inclusion of their names in the register
In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the companyvictions of the appellants under B.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 explicitly states that the non-inclusion does not constitute an offence under s.92, undercutting the application of the penalty provision in concept c4.

anchor.surface_text: As they were not workers, the non-inclusion of their names in the register of adult workers or the absence of any entries in regard to them in the said register would not constitute an offence under s. 92 of the Act.
In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the companyvictions of the appellants under B.
